Write me the start of a script for a movie scene, with dialogue, based on the below information:

Two directors of Arena Television, the failed outside broadcast business at the centre of the UK’s “largest ever” asset-based lending fraud, were made bankrupt after failing to respond to a High Court judgment ordering repayment of £100 million.
According to the latest insolvency filing for Arena, which collapsed last November and is suspected of defrauding lenders out of about £280 million, its owner, Richard Yeowart, and co-director Robert Hopkinson, had initially been asked to repay £250 million.
When the directors, whose whereabouts are still thought to be unknown, did not respond, insolvency practitioners from Kroll pursued a default judgment via the High Court. This was granted in the sum of £100 million, plus costs of £500,000, an administrators’ report shows, said to be the amount the judge was initially satisfied was owed by Yeowart and Hopkinson. The pair were made bankrupt in February after failing to respond to the statutory demand, administrators said.
A further hearing can be requested to increase the value of the default judgment if it is deemed this could improve returns to creditors.
Arena was incorporated in 1988 and worked on sports and events including the European football championship for ITV Sport and Glastonbury festival for the BBC.
Yeowart ordered it to cease trading in November after a concern was raised that an asset linked to a loan may not exist. Administrators subsequently found the company had borrowed against equipment that either did not exist, or had already been used to secure a loan from another lender.
The suspected scam is thought to be one of the largest frauds to have hit the asset-based lending industry, with 55 lenders owed £282 million, much of which is likely to be lost. Insolvency practitioners have alleged that 46 lenders, owed a combined £182 million, “do not have recourse to any assets” underlying their lending, with a shortfall of “several thousand assets”.
It is understood that Yeowart, 54, and Hopkinson, 41, were living in France before the alleged scam was uncovered and hadn’t been seen at Arena’s premises in Redhill, Surrey, for some time before the group’s failure.
Yeowart has outright ownership in properties in the UK, France and Spain but the combined identified assets of the directors are understood to be worth only a small proportion of the amount owed. A £1.5 million property in Barcelona owned by Yeowart is being held on trust following the judgment.
A worldwide freezing injunction was obtained against both directors last November. The freezing injunction has also been served on “various third parties” that received money from Arena or its directors, administrators said.
The Serious Fraud Office began a criminal investigation into the scandal in February, when two arrests were made of unnamed individuals and three properties were searched. Yeowart and Hopkinson were not arrested.
Areas of interest include Arena’s relationship with third parties including Sentinel Broadcast, a supplier of audiovisual equipment based in Hook, Hampshire.
According to court filings first reported by The Sunday Times, Yeowart used a Hong Kong entity called Sports Online to perpetrate a complex alleged fraud involving fake equipment and complicit third parties to steal funds from lenders. Shawbrook, HSBC, Lombard, ABN Amro and Close Leasing are among those exposed to the scandal.

A locked room in Arena TV’s headquarters in Redhill, Surrey, formed the centre of a scheme to defraud lenders out of £282 million. There, Arena’s owner, Richard Yeowart, forged labels with false serial numbers as he cooked up a plan that was to become the UK’s biggest-ever fraud in asset-backed lending.
Explosive court filings in a civil claim against Yeowart and his fellow director Robert Hopkinson allege how the pair spent company funds on cryptocurrency, a house in Barcelona costing €1.8 million (£1.5 million), and transferred £950,000 from the company to a personal bank account.
Arena TV collapsed into insolvency last November, two days after Yeowart sent an email to staff telling them to cease trading, leaving more than 50 lenders nursing heavy losses related to debts secured against equipment that either did not exist, or had already been secured by another lender.
Yeowart, 54 and Hopkinson, 41, have since absconded, their whereabouts unknown.
Administrators from Kroll said that 55 lenders, including high street banks such as NatWest and Clydesdale Bank and a string of boutique lenders, had provided hundreds of millions in loans. Most were secured against assets that did not exist. Only nine of them had any verified assets to back up their lending.
Founded in 1988, Arena TV provided outside broadcast services to everything from the Six Nations rugby to Glastonbury festival. The company, which had bases in Redhill and Biggin Hill, in Kent, provided trucks, equipment, such as cameras, and services to customers including the BBC, Sky Sports and ITV. When it collapsed, its trucks were already on the way to Wembley to cover an England game.
The Serious Fraud Office launched a criminal investigation, and last month announced the arrests of two individuals, understood to be separate from the defendants in the civil claim.
Yeowart, described as a “quiet man” by his former employees, is a former cameraman with a passion for aircraft, who regularly commuted to work in a helicopter from his home in East Grinstead, West Sussex. Hopkinson joined the company in 2003 and was marketing director.
In December 2019, when it last filed financial statementsbefore its collapse, Arena Holdings reported sales of £33.6 million, up from £32.9 million in 2018. It also reported pre-tax profits of £4.2 million, up from £3.2 million a year earlier.
However, details have emerged about the alleged fraud since the company’s collapse. Court filings, brought against Yeowart and Hopkinson by administrators to Arena, allege a complex fraud involving a company registered in Hong Kong, undisclosed bank accounts and complicit intermediaries.
In 2012, Yeowart set up a new company, Sports Online Limited, registered in Hong Kong. According to court filings, Sports Online was used by Yeowart to perpetrate the fraud.
It is alleged that through a circular scheme, he would arrange for the wrongful “sale” of equipment by Arena or Sports Online to an intermediary company, which appeared to be involved in the alleged fraud. The intermediary then sold it on to an asset-backed lender. This “equipment”, much of which did not exist, would then be the subject of a hire purchase agreement between Arena and the lender, which did not handle the goods itself.
According to the claim, Yeowart would send pictures of the equipment with their false serial numbers — along with false certificates — to the lender to show that Arena had taken delivery of it.
This was done to conceal the fact that the equipment did not exist and had not been procured from a third-party supplier in the ordinary course of business.
It is also alleged that Yeowart told the intermediaries the price to be put on these false invoices — substantially in excess of the market price. The intermediaries were paid a commission of 1 per cent of the inflated purchase price.
Arena allegedly operated undisclosed bank accounts, which were used to carry out the fraudulent schemes.
Along with creating false invoices, Yeowart is accused of misappropriating company funds.
In September 2019, he opened a cryptocurrency account with Luno Money, transferring €275,280 and £480,500 of company money into the account. He also transferred £950,000 from the company to an account in his name. In the same year, Hopkinson and Yeowart used €1.8 million of company money to buy a seafront home in Sitges, close to Barcelona. Sitges has been described as the Saint-Tropez of Spain thanks to its glitzy beach crowd. Arena’s remaining assets have been auctioned off and staff still have little clue about what went on behind Yeowart’s locked door.
A defence has not been filed.
The investigation into an alleged fraud at the outside broadcaster Arena TV has widened, after a High Court claim named a further employee at the company.
Kroll, the administrator to Arena, has filed a claim against Nicholas Cousins, who is understood to have held a senior finance job at the company.
Arena TV collapsed in November, two days after its founder, Richard Yeowart, ordered it to stop trading. Lenders were left more than £280 million out of pocket in what is thought to be the biggest ever alleged scam in asset-backed lending. Its demise left more than 50 lenders nursing losses of hundreds of millions of pounds that had been secured equipment, much of which did not exist.
Yeowart, 54, and fellow director Robert Hopkinson, 41, were made bankrupt in their absence after failing to respond to a High Court judgment ordering repayment of £100 million.
Now, Kroll appears to have extended its case to include Cousins, a long-standing employee of Arena. Former employees said Cousins had left the company several weeks before it ceased trading. The nature of the claim against Cousins, who could not be reached for comment, is not yet known.
Arena TV was established in 1988 and worked on big events including Glastonbury and the Euros football championship. The company, which had bases in Redhill, Surrey, and Biggin Hill, Kent, provided trucks, equipment and services to customers including the BBC, Sky Sports and ITV. Trucks had already arrived at Wembley Stadium in preparation for England’s match against Albania on November 12, and were told to return to base when the company ceased trading.
Explosive court filings later alleged Yeowart had forged labels and created false serial numbers in a locked room in Arena’s headquarters. It is alleged that he then spent company funds on cryptocurrency, a house in Barcelona costing €1.8 million, and transferred £950,000 from the company to a personal bank account.
Some 55 lenders, including high street banks such as NatWest and Clydesdale, had provided hundreds of millions in loans. Since the administration, Arena’s remaining assets have been auctioned off.
In its progress report from last month, Kroll said it would continue to identify and pursue claims against third parties. It is assessing Yeowart’s international property portfolio, and his house in Spain is being sold, according to the report. Kroll did not respond to a request for comment.

The scale of an alleged fraud at a television business has been laid bare by administrators who estimate that about £280 million may have been borrowed against thousands of fake assets.

Arena Television, whose directors’ whereabouts remain unknown, collapsed into insolvency in November two days after its founder and owner, Richard Yeowart, suddenly ordered it to cease trading after a concern was raised that an asset used to get a loan may not exist.
Yeowart, 54, and his co-director Robert Hopkinson, 41, are said to have absconded and scores of lenders face difficult questions over why they appear to have lent hundreds of millions of pounds with no true security to underpin the debts.

Arena was incorporated in 1988 and worked on sports and events coverage as an outside broadcast specialist, including ITV Sport’s European football championship coverage and FA Cup coverage for the BBC, as well as the Wimbledon tennis championships, T20 cricket and Glastonbury music festival.
Administrators from Kroll have found that the Arena group secured more than £290 million against supposed assets, thousands of which are now suspected to never have existed. Fifty-five lenders are owed £282 million relating to broadcast assets. Insolvency practitioners allege, however, that the group “does not hold the vast majority of assets” purportedly borrowed against, filings show.

Only nine of the fifty-five lenders have any verified assets supporting their lending. The remainder, owed a combined £182 million, “do not have recourse to any assets” underlying their lending, administrators said, noting that there is a shortfall of “several thousand assets”.
They are investigating several matters including “materially significant liabilities which do not align with the group’s audited and management accounts”.
Among those facing the biggest losses are Shawbrook, owed £34.6 million, HSBC, owed £29.5 million, Lombard, owed £24.2 million, and ABN Amro, owed £22.6 million. Alongside high street banks such as Lloyds and NatWest, scores of non-bank and boutique lenders are also caught up in the alleged scam.
According to his profile on IMDB, the film and games industry information dashboard, Yeowart has worked on television shows including Surprise! Surprise! and Ant & Dec’s Saturday Night Takeaway.
Kroll said that Yeowart had ordered the company to cease trading on November 10 at a point when a number of the company’s assets were at, or on the way to, sites for outside broadcast jobs. It emerged that this was after an agent of a lender had conducted an asset verification exercise.
While attempting to verify a serial number of an asset Arena had borrowed against, the equipment supplier told the agent that “no such serial number existed”. The next day Close Leasing, a specialist lender, approached Kroll and administrators were appointed on November 12. Three more group companies including Arena Aviation, an aerial filing provider for Sky News and BBC News and an operator of private jets and VIP helicopter trips, are now also in administration.
Yeowart and Hopkinson are subject to worldwide asset freezing injunctions that have also been served on banks holding accounts in their name or those of Arena companies, as well as upon “various third parties that may have received monies from the companies or directors or may hold assets on their behalf”, Kroll said.
Upon appointment the administrators were told that the directors had left the UK and attempts to contact them by Kroll, “other stakeholders and regulatory bodies, including the High Court”, had been unsuccessful.
As well as the “substantial shortall of assets”, the administrators said that they were also investigating matters such as the abrupt closure of the business, the “abscondment of the directors” and “misinformation” allegedly provided to lenders and others.
The group appears to have little money in the bank. The administrators are selling off Arena’s assets to recover money for creditors but said that it was too early to provide a reliable estimate of how much might be returned.
The Times revealed in November that the state-owned British Business Bank is investigating circumstances surrounding the granting of taxpayer guarantees on certain loans made to the business during the pandemic.
Two men linked to the Arena TV scandal are being sued by the company’s administrators for £285 million over claims they were involved in an unlawful conspiracy against scores of lenders.
Paul Froom, of Sentinel Broadcast, a supplier to Arena, and Nicholas Cousins, thought to have held a senior finance role at Arena, have been accused of providing “dishonest assistance” to Richard Yeowart and Robert Hopkinson, the television company’s directors.
In a further development in what is thought to be one of the largest alleged scams ever to hit Britain’s asset-based lending industry, The Times has learnt that Hopkinson has been found in France by local law enforcement.
The Serious Fraud Office is understood to be in contact with the French authorities over access to Hopkinson, 41. The whereabouts of Yeowart, 54, are thought to remain unknown.
A High Court claim against Froom and Cousins shows the former is being pursued over £1.1 million of invoices paid to Sentinel, a sum said to have been “misapplied and/or misappropriated” by Arena’s directors. Cousins received £210,000 in “corrupt gifts” for his role in the scam, administrators claim.
Arena, an outside broadcast specialist, collapsed in November and is suspected of defrauding high street banks and specialist finance houses of £280 million. The company was incorporated in 1988 and worked on sports events including the European football championship for ITV Sport and the Glastonbury Festival for the BBC.
Yeowart ordered the group to cease trading last November after a concern was raised on behalf of a lender that an asset linked to a loan may not exist.
Insolvency practitioners from Kroll found the company had borrowed funds against equipment that either did not exist or had already been used to secure debt from other lenders.
Administrators have alleged that 46 lenders, owed a combined £182 million, “do not have recourse to any assets” underlying their lending, with a shortfall of “several thousand assets”.
The fraud office is thought to be in contact with Eurojust, a pan-European body that helps national authorities to co-ordinate action against organised crime, over Hopkinson.
Yeowart has been accused of forging labels on equipment and creating false serial numbers and of spending some of the funds on cryptocurrency and property.
In June, Hopkinson and Yeowart were made bankrupt after failing to respond to a High Court judgment ordering the repayment of £100 million. The claim against Froom, 48, and Cousins includes £285 million for “damages for unlawful means conspiracy”. It is the estimated total deficit of Arena.
Sentinel Broadcast is a supplier of audiovisual equipment in Hook, Hampshire. The company, which was placed in administration in July, was a “preferred” supplier for Arena. Sentinel is suspected of creating false invoices and the veracity of serial numbers relating to supposed assets ostensibly supplied by Sentinel is in question.
Froom was asked for comment. Cousins, Hopkinson and Yeowart could not be reached. Eurojust, Kroll and the fraud office declined to comment.
Administrators at Arena Television are looking into the possible role of a supplier in an alleged scam at the outside broadcaster, which is accused of borrowing £280 million against thousands of non-existent assets.
Arena’s relationship with Sentinel Broadcast, a supplier of audiovisual equipment based in Hook, Hampshire, is a key line of inquiry for the insolvency practitioners, The Times understands.
Arena, whose directors’ whereabouts are unknown, collapsed into insolvency in November, two days after Richard Yeowart, its founder and owner, suddenly ordered it to cease trading after a concern was raised that an asset linked to a loan may not exist.
Yeowart, 54, and Robert Hopkinson, 41, a co-director, are said to have absconded and administrators from Kroll, the consulting firm, have estimated that 55 lenders are owed £282 million relating to debts ostensibly secured against broadcasting assets.
Insolvency practitioners allege that 46 lenders, owed a combined £182 million, “do not have recourse to any assets” underlying their lending, with a shortfall of “several thousand assets”, resulting in embarrassment for high street banks and specialist lenders.
Sentinel Broadcast was a “preferred” supplier for Arena, the term for a supplier with a trusted relationship with a commercial customer. It is understood that the veracity of serial numbers related to supposed assets ostensibly supplied by Sentinel is being examined.
When asked about the company’s relationship with Arena, Paul Froom, 47, director of Sentinel, said: “I don’t really have a comment at the minute.” He did not respond to an invitation to comment on whether Sentinel had any role in the alleged asset shortfall.
Arena was incorporated in 1988 and worked on sports and events coverage, including the European football championship for ITV Sport and FA Cup coverage for the BBC.
The alleged fraud is understood to have gone undetected for a long time as Arena kept up with loan repayments. It was uncovered when a manufacturer told a lender’s agent that a serial number for leased equipment did not exist.
The use of broadcast assets in an alleged scam complicates matters for lenders as they are rarely at the borrower’s headquarters for checks. If an equipment supplier or vendor played a role in the alleged scam, it could make it harder for lenders to detect.
Ian Gough-Williams, a director at Thameside TV, an occasional supplier to Sentinel where Arena was the end user, said he was surprised at questions over Sentinel’s role in the case.
“We have only ever had a professional relationship with Sentinel, where we were paid as per our invoice terms,” he said.
Administrators, who have launched a claim for breach of fiduciary duty against Yeowart and Hopkinson, did not respond to an invitation to comment. The Serious Fraud Office has refused to comment on suggestions that it may launch an inquiry.
The Financial Conduct Authority is under pressure to look into apparent due diligence failures by lenders.
These include Shawbrook, owed £34.6 million, HSBC, owed £29.5 million, Lombard, owed £24.2 million, and ABN Amro, owed £22.6 million.
Alongside high street banks such as Lloyds, scores of non-bank and boutique lenders are also caught up in the alleged scam. More than 70 staff of Arena are owed almost £1.3 million in unpaid wages.

Staff at Arena Television are owed almost £1.3 million in unpaid wages after the firm collapsed into administration amid fraud allegations.
More than 70 employees are among the creditors owed millions of pounds after the outside broadcaster was discovered to have taken out almost £300 million in loans. Administrators to Arena said it had secured more than £280 million against assets that did not exist.
They are investigating alleged fraud and have launched a legal claim against the company’s two former directors, Richard Yeowart and Robert Hopkinson, who are being sued for breach of fiduciary duty. The two men have not been seen at Arena’s premises since December 2020 and have left the country.
After Kroll was appointed administrator in November, it made most staff redundant. A former senior employee at Arena said he was owed about £6,000 in unpaid wages, and that he was furious it was taking so long to be paid. “The people who gave their lives to the business get stung,” he said. “To be treated like a corporate number is shocking ... There are human beings who have gone through mental breakdowns through all this uncertainty.”
The collapse of Arena has left hundreds of creditors out of pocket. According to filings lodged last week with Companies House, Arena owes £155,971 to HMRC and £2 million to trade creditors. Just over 70 employees are owed £1.3 million.
Electra trust slips into comfier shoes
Electra Private Equity, once one of London’s highest-profile investment trusts, will announce the final stage of a break-up tomorrow that was sparked by activist investor Edward Bramson (Jill Treanor writes).
Electra will no longer be listed on the main segment of the stock market and will transform into a comfy shoe business, Hotter, with a market valuation of about £27 million. It will relist on the junior Aim market under the new name of Unbound on January 31.
Ian Watson, who became chief executive of Hotter in 2019 and oversaw a company voluntary arrangement in 2020 to allow 58 store closures, will head the newly listed business.
Its stock market valuation is significantly below the £84 million that Electra paid for Hotter in 2014, just before Bramson started building his 30 per cent stake in the trust. He no longer has a holding.
It is the last of about 20 investments made by Electra, which has sold off the manufacturer Sentinel and last year listed TGI Fridays restaurants under the name Hostmore.
Watson has big plans for Hotter to grow by teaming up with other retailers. It is now mainly an online business aimed at the over-55s and wants to harness its database of 4.6 million customers. It is in advanced talks with potential partners.
Electra had a market value of £1.1 billion when Bramson arrived and has since returned £2.1 billion to shareholders, under the chairmanship of Neil Johnson, who joined in May 2016.

Administrators to Arena Television are suing its former directors for breach of fiduciary duty amid allegations of a huge fraud at the collapsed broadcaster.
Administrators from Kroll filed a claim in the High Court last week against Arena TV’s former owner and managing director, Richard Yeowart, and Robert Hopkinson, another former director. The company collapsed suddenly this month.
A source close to the administration said the collapse was set in motion when an auditor, acting for one of Arena TV’s lenders, attempted to verify serial numbers for company-owned equipment used as security for loans. When the auditor called the equipment suppliers, they were told the serial numbers did not exist.
“It is potentially the biggest fraud of this kind the UK has ever seen,” the source said.
Administrators have been unable to contact Yeowart, 54, who is believed to be in France. Attempts by The Sunday Times to contact Yeowart were unsuccessful. Hopkinson, 41, did not reply to a request for comment.
Arena TV, founded in 1988, became one of the largest independent outside broadcasters in the UK, serving customers including the BBC, ITV and Sky Sports. According to his LinkedIn profile, Hopkinson joined in 2003, a year after leaving university.
Arena TV is understood to have borrowed about £300 million from asset-based lenders including HSBC, Close Brothers and Shawbrook, according to Sky News. Allied Irish Bank is also said to have lent to Arena TV. Recoveries from administration are likely to be minimal.
The company’s equipment was used to produce ITV’s coverage of Euro 2020, and this year’s FA Cup Final was remotely produced at Arena TV’s headquarters in Redhill, Surrey. Its large outside-broadcast trucks have been deployed at the Glastonbury festival and the Olympics.
Arena Aviation, a separate division, has been providing aerial filming services since the mid-1990s and operated news-gathering helicopters for big networks when it collapsed. The outside- broadcast industry has been steadily consolidating amid tough competition, with many of Arena’s rivals bought by international firms.
In 2019, the last year for which accounts are available, the group reported pre-tax profits of £3.8 million on sales of £29.6 million. The company reported that it had assets worth £58.6 million.
Its accounts were signed off by auditors from McKenzies, a small practice based in Surrey.
Arena employed about 100 people at the time of its collapse.

Police are understood to be closing in on the owner of collapsed Arena TV after tracking him down to a home in France.
Sources said French police were aware of the location of Richard Yeowart, who ran the outside broadcast supplier until its collapse in November. Yeowart, 54, and fellow director Robert Hopkinson, 41, are said to have absconded to a location near the resort of Le Touquet, just south of Calais. Administrators from Kroll have estimated that 55 lenders are owed £282 million in loans secured against equipment that, in many cases, appears not to have existed.
The investigation has also expanded to Arena’s relationship with one of its suppliers, Sentinel Broadcast, which supplies audiovisual equipment. A source close to the administration said they were investigating whether Sentinel had created false invoices in co-operation with Arena.
Arena was founded by Yeowart more than 30 years ago, and provided outside broadcast services to everything from the Six Nations rugby to Glastonbury. The company, which had bases in Redhill in Surrey and Biggin Hill in Kent, provided trucks and equipment to customers including the BBC, Sky Sports and ITV.
However, on November 10 last year, Yeowart sent an email to senior staff saying that the company was closing down. Over the next couple of days, Arena’s 100 or so employees scrambled around, wondering what to do. Trucks belonging to the company, which had already arrived at Wembley Stadium in preparation for England’s match against Albania on Friday, November 12, were told to return to base. Arena’s customer, ITV, was forced to find a new supplier, and Arena’s staff were left in limbo.
The collapse is one of the largest alleged frauds ever to hit the asset-based lending industry.
Since then, details have emerged about Yeowart’s extravagant lifestyle. The former cameraman has a passion for aircraft and regularly commuted to work by helicopter. Arena owned a fleet, plus three jets, and Yeowart is believed to have a pilot’s licence.
According to Land Registry records, Yeowart owns a cottage in East Grinstead, West Sussex, where he is believed to have been living with. Hopkinson was marketing director at Arena having joined in 2003 from university.
Both men are subject to world-wide asset-freezing injunctions that have also been served on banks with accounts in their name.
Paul Froom, the director of Sentinel, is said to have appointed criminal defence lawyers. He declined to comment. Yeowart could not be reached for comment.

Le Touquet is a chi-chi seaside town in France, just south of Calais, loved by the British since the 1920s. As of last month, it is also thought to be near where Richard Yeowart, chief executive of the scandal-hit broadcast company Arena Television, is camped out.
Yeowart, 54, left Britain early last month as the company he began more than 30 years ago collapsed into administration, leaving 100 staff worried for their futures and a trail of lenders facing losses of almost £300 million. Sources suggest it could be the biggest scandal in the history of UK asset-backed lending.
Administrators to Arena, which provided outside broadcast services to everything from the Six Nations rugby to Glastonbury, are investigating alleged fraud and have launched a legal claim against Yeowart and fellow director Robert Hopkinson, suing the pair for breach of fiduciary duty. One lender, United Trust, has also begun a claim against Yeowart for breach of contract, adding it was “seeking to protect” its interests.
Now it can be revealed that furloughed staff complained of being told to return to work at Arena while still being paid by the government-backed wages scheme. Multiple members of staff told the Sunday Times they were on furlough during this period and attended the company’s offices for shifts. When they complained, they were told by email that the “entire company must work together as a team” to get through Covid. They were told they should perform these tasks “without exception” and to disregard guidance from the Citizens Advice Bureau to the contrary.
Arena, which was founded by Yeowart in 1988, grew to become one of the UK’s biggest independent outside broadcasters. The company, which has bases in Redhill in Surrey and Biggin Hill in Kent, provided trucks, equipment and services to customers including the BBC, Sky Sports and ITV. It has worked on events from Glastonbury to the Olympics and the Wimbledon tennis championship.
Despite his company’s prominence in the industry, little is known personally about Yeowart, a former cameraman who is said to have a passion for aircraft and regularly commuted to work in a helicopter; Arena owned a fleet, plus three jets, and he is believed to hold a helicopter pilot’s licence. “His first love was aviation,” an ex-employee said.
Another former employee described Yeowart as a “very quiet man” who was “straightforward, kind and honest”. The company provided the equipment to Ariana Grande’s tribute concert for victims of the Manchester Arena attack, held in 2017 at Old Trafford, free of charge. “It felt like a family company to work for,” said the former staff member.
According to Land Registry records, Yeowart owns a cottage in East Grinstead, West Sussex, where he is believed to have been living with Hopkinson, who was marketing director at Arena having joined in 2003 from university. The pair are the sole directors of the company.
In December 2019, when it last filed financial statements, Arena Holdings reported sales of £33.6 million, up from £32.9 million in 2018. It also reported pre-tax profits of £4.2 million, from £3.2 million a year earlier. “We expect that British broadcasters will continue to see the merits of supporting a well-established, British-owned company that pays all its taxes in the UK,” its accounts boasted, before adding: “The business is not for sale and will remain in the same family ownership for many years to come.”
Once Covid hit, however, Arena’s business struggled, according to former insiders. This time last year, about 19 members of staff were made redundant. Arena also took on more debt, with The Times reporting last week that it was granted a series of taxpayer-backed loans, including £800,000 via the coronavirus business interruption loan scheme (Cbils).
With events cancelled, Arena Television placed employees on furlough and claimed £360,000 to £725,000 in wage payments between December 2020 and August 2021, the period for which data is available. It is not known how much Arena claimed in furlough wages during the first lockdown, as these figures have not been made public.
Staff members allege they were scheduled to work shifts for “maintenance” or “housekeeping” at Arena’s offices while their wages were being paid by the taxpayer. Furlough rules forbid any work that provides services for the employer. It is understood that staff were told that any furloughed employees required to participate in such tasks would be contacted by their head of department and scheduled a day. Staff are understood to have approached Citizens Advice for guidance and were told by Arena that the work was permissible while on furlough.
A former senior employee, who was in charge of managing team members, said staff were rostered in for “essential maintenance”, adding they were so afraid for their jobs they may have gone to work when they should not have. The executive responsible for instructing staff on the matter, Peter Love, Arena’s director of operations, did not reply to a request to comment. HMRC said it would not comment on “identifiable businesses”.
Arena’s real trouble began last month, when one of its lenders attempted to verify serial numbers for company-owned equipment that was being used as security for loans. When the auditor rang the supplier, they were told the numbers did not exist.
On November 10, staff received an email from Yeowart: it said that the company had ceased trading and they should go home. Later that afternoon, an email was sent to clients: “I’m very sad to say that Arena TV has ceased trading with effect from today, Wednesday, November 10. All bookings have been cancelled.”
Over the next couple of days, Arena’s 100 or so employees scrambled around, wondering what to do. Trucks belonging to the company, which had already arrived at Wembley Stadium in preparation for England’s match against Albania on Friday, November 12, were told to return to base; Arena’s customer, ITV, was forced to find a new supplier.
“By Thursday morning there was a bit of a panic about what was going on,” said a source familiar with the administration. “Staff didn’t know what was happening.”
ITV was forced to find a new supplier for England’s 5-0 win over Albania, when Harry Kane scored a hat trick
ITV was forced to find a new supplier for England’s 5-0 win over Albania, when Harry Kane scored a hat trick
LAURENCE GRIFFITHS/GETTY IMAGES
More lenders now became aware that the company had ceased trading — and the debt figure began to grow inexorably.
“As people started to wake up to it, more lenders came out of the woodwork, saying ‘we’re owed X million’,” said a source with knowledge of the administration. It is now thought that there could be more than 20 lenders with a claim, with Arena’s total debts reaching £280 million. Among them are NatWest, Shawbrook and Close Brothers, which lodged the administration application with the High Court. Kroll was appointed as administrator on November 12.
The scale of the alleged fraud has sent shockwaves through the industry. “This is pretty unprecedented stuff and the finance industry will be looking hard for lessons to learn,” said Will Wright, head of restructuring at Interpath Advisory.
The Times reported last week that the British Business Bank is investigating payments that were granted to Arena by lenders accredited to provide taxpayer-backed pandemic loans in the months leading up to its collapse.
Now the hunt begins: to piece together the scale of the alleged fraud. Kroll is understood to have appointed an investigator to look for any missing equipment. “As part of the administration process, Kroll has instructed an agent to undertake an inventory of its assets on the company’s premises, as is standard in these situations,” said Ben Wiles, the joint administrator.
In the meantime, employees are still waiting for answers. “We’re all frustratingly still waiting to find out what’s going to happen, if any redundancy or owed time or expenses will even get paid,” said one current employee. “Some of us are owed a great deal.” Answers are unlikely to come from Yeowart, however. Two days before the company ceased trading, he resigned from his family’s agricultural business in East Sussex. Last week, he could not be reached for comment.

A television business at the heart of a fraud investigation secured millions of pounds of taxpayer-backed pandemic loans in the run-up to its collapse.
Arena Television arranged credit that came with state guarantees attached as it ran up debts thought to be in the region of £280 million from a vast array of lenders, drawing the government’s emergency loan schemes and much of the commercial lending industry into the emerging scandal. Administrators of the London-based business, which failed last week, are investigating an alleged fraud and are suing its directors Richard Yeowart, 54, and Robert Hopkinson, 41, for breach of fiduciary duty.
The collapse was set in motion when an auditor acting for one of Arena TV’s lenders tried to verify serial numbers for company-owned equipment used as security for loans, according to The Sunday Times. When the auditor called the equipment suppliers, they were told the numbers did not exist.
Arena was incorporated in 1988 and worked on big sports and events coverage, including ITV Sport’s European football championship and FA Cup coverage for the BBC, as well as the Glastonbury music festival.
The state-owned British Business Bank, which administers the emergency finance schemes, is investigating the circumstances surrounding the granting of loans to Arena by lenders that it had accredited to provide credit to help companies to survive the pandemic.
Arena was granted a series of these taxpayer-guaranteed loans, including £800,000 secured via the coronavirus business interruption loan scheme last year and separate credit provided under the recovery loan scheme, which was launched in April. Arena’s state-backed loans are understood to run into millions of pounds.
There is shock in the commercial lending industry at the scale of the alleged fraud, with swathes of the high street and alternative asset-based lending industry caught up. Scores of lenders are facing losses, including HSBC, NatWest, Santander, Shawbrook and Clydesdale. As well as loans allegedly secured against non-existent equipment, lenders are also understood to be concerned that Arena might have managed to fraudulently arrange debts from several providers secured against the same asset.
Arena’s accounts for 2019 show annual sales of £29.6 million, with £29.8 million of debt linked to leasing agreements — little more than a tenth of what is thought to be its true level of exposure.
While fraud in the asset finance industry is a perennial risk, a senior source in the industry said that the sheer variety of borrowers exposed to what was a relatively small business was unprecedented. Another said that they feared it could turn out to be “the biggest fraud in asset finance”.
The case is likely to raise questions about how the company managed to pass underwriting processes at so many lenders. Arena also claimed between £360,000 and £725,000 in wage furlough payments from the taxpayer between December 2020 and August 2021.
According to his profile on IMDB, the film and games industry information dashboard, Yeowart, Arena’s founder, has worked on television shows including Ant & Dec’s Saturday Night Takeaway and Spitting Image.
Yeowart, who was said to be in France, could not be reached for comment. Hopkinson was approached for comment.
The scandal could result in fresh scrutiny on the lack of regulation of commercial lending, an issue already in the spotlight in the wake of the Greensill Capital saga, as well as on due diligence standards at lenders and the British Business Bank. Before the collapse in March of Greensill, a supply chain lender, it was provided with about £400 million of state-backed guarantees. Most of these related to loans to companies in the Gupta Family Group Alliance — a breach of lending limits — and £335 million is thought to be at risk. The British Business Bank was accused by MPs this month of “woefully inadequate” due diligence.
Under the coronavirus business interruption loan scheme and the recovery loan scheme, the state provided an 80 per cent guarantee on sums advanced by lenders that they can call on if the borrower defaults. The recovery loan scheme coverage drops to 70 per cent in January.
A British Business Bank spokesman said: “We are currently investigating facilities granted to Arena through accredited lenders using the bank’s schemes, and expect lenders to work with the company’s administrators on recoveries.”
A spokesman for Kroll, Arena��s administrator, declined to comment.
